861540F16BE0430D974D4F6B2983363C.description: Present research findings regarding wildlife and habitat management-related occupations.

CFA6AE3BAF684B18BD09DCA6D041FC9C.description: Research experience and qualifications for newcomers to enter the wildlife and habitat management field.

A084B5C3401244BD9AD528655BE75848.description: Explore opportunities for underrepresented populations in the wildlife and habitat management field.

96BB1194E67842E6BD5492596690B95A.description: Reflect upon personal suitability or non-suitability for a specific wildlife and habitat management-related occupation considering criteria such as: initial and continuing educational requirements; duties and skills required for this occupation; the work environment, including typical hours and shift worked and typical locations; current wages received in Saskatchewan and how these compare to the rest of Canada; physical, mental and emotional stresses related to this occupation; workplace hazards and safety considerations; other occupations with which they interact; apprenticeship and/or certification requirements in Canada and Saskatchewan; and, future trends impacting wildlife and habitat management-related careers.

10C8E91C960846A3853BF670C295FBA9.description: Examine the roles, responsibilities, educational qualifications and personal and professional qualities common in wildlife and habitat management careers.

054A02ED2F0E4165ABD1364F710F4234.description: Research which wildlife and habitat management-related occupations are facing shortages and which are oversubscribed locally, regionally or provincially.

A1880396701742B0AC1493A0D244E3F1.description: Develop a list of career opportunities (e.g., wildlife biologist, environmental technician and conservation officer) related to the field of wildlife and habitat management.

D6390BEB9B01418D9C239123DA0161B4.description: Create a list of personal interests, skills and traits that could lead to a career in wildlife and habitat management.

353CA1AA1CED474A8274B028BF320BF6.description: Identify careers in the area of wildlife and habitat management.

55E00F87E82C496F9F844E00B40311EC.description: Explore career opportunities in the field of wildlife and habitat management.

8C48E0D284BF4C73904378DA947228B8.description: Trace the evolution of natural resource responsibility in Saskatchewan from federal to provincial governments.

FA8459DD2FAD4EF7827722DE9F92715D.description: Describe the evolution of wildlife management practices to include the management of habitat and ecosystems.

EBD190294B2C48529E4A40BE1773934C.description: Explain the purpose of the Treaty Land Sharing Network.

217C3BE1B176433DA8923013AF907B7F.description: Investigate the connection between treaties and the hunting, fishing and trapping rights of Indigenous people.

1484266559D94F0D8463E8A166CD03B2.description: Examine the impacts of historical uses of wildlife resources (e.g., bison and beaver) on Indigenous people's way of life.

0DDB2412D547446A9FFE664E77507913.description: Explore how the historical philosophy of dominion over animals has evolved to a philosophy of managing resources.

B6A5ECDA3FF348C38178E946489E5329.description: Discuss the history and evolution of wildlife and habitat management.

E56F7072EB0F429384D5C0B3E9819593.description: Plan for hydration and nutrition requirements appropriate to the excursion.

6F7A05FE61DF43E9A2079DA9DBFADB97.description: Evaluate possible risks (e.g., weather, terrain, animals and plants) that may be encountered.

8B749EBE01A6468CB345A42614BB7CE6.description: Identify the route, possible exit points and muster point for the excursion.

E2587DED4C4C44D6AB0377EA394EE86D.description: Establish communication routines (e.g., whistle commands and carry contact information) in emergency situations both within and outside of cell phone range.

97F4497102CA4B42AFB617EF034E6985.description: Identify which supplies are required for the excursion.

D4B0A486FA284BE298C4949E01D37897.description: Investigate the principles of layering clothing and appropriate fabric choices depending on the season, weather conditions and activity.

F20E0FC047804028B44488F040170D86.description: Explore short excursion options appropriate for the season and group, such as: investigate deer density in local area; reflect on personal growth with a sit-spot; identify animal tracks; and, record plant observations.

47D5CE9712EF44C4A7FF1FE495E07C8E.description: Reflect upon the traditional stories of the land where the local excursion will take place.

308C95BEF0C04BE6AC818F37C52A169A.description: Discuss the importance of land acknowledgements (e.g., naming the traditional peoples of the area, identifying the treaty and partnerships with local Indigenous people) when participating in local excursions.

6028A6F1A3DA4B54A2AEF1EF827E32BD.description: Plan and facilitate an outdoor excursion in the local community.

4E05F79496B04560B28E4061420E7886.description: Employ effective communication skills (e.g., active listening and positive body language) in various situations.

CBAC4A5E70AF4CEA9515C72D6DD0D95C.description: Explain the importance of effective communication in group living.

06286A54C5F943E58FA179A18735DA57.description: Exhibit cooperative behaviour in partner recreational activities (e.g., wall climbing and canoe paddling).

8C884264CBE54CF3B9F73302E98EBAC1.description: Analyze the importance of establishing group norms.

39D59F8E5F514DC79D958988022D7BF3.description: Identify rules and norms (e.g., sharing responsibility, contributing to the group’s activities and respecting others) for effective group living.

6D1DF57B21C44CB69B83EFB90BA5B8F8.description: Implement constructive problem-solving strategies, including eliciting input from each group member.

3B63E60187514FE98AE014CB267280A3.description: Describe the various roles required to work effectively as a group in outdoor living situations, such as meal preparation and shelter building.

08D49D948ED14F2A84714FD48DB7AC58.description: Explore examples of how group cooperation was employed in Indigenous ways of living (e.g., hide tanning, rope making and shelter building).

541D53531B164A1685DA3D4C0DE7DF51.description: Discuss the importance of cooperative living in communities in different cultures (e.g., Indigenous, Asian and Nordic), including a shared sense of responsibility for the good of the collective.

B0622D09C2FD45F4A65E6068FB118635.description: Participate in a variety of team-building activities.

BDB9A4A579704B90B65345F7472EED66.description: Explore examples of teamwork in nature (e.g., geese's flying formation).

B2ED897488D34CCA8697F9B974121D6D.description: Explore solutions to climate change, such as: reducing one's “carbon footprint” (e.g., public transportation); community regulations (e.g., no plastic bags); alternative (e.g., solar, geothermal, hydro and wind power) energy sources; and advocating for stronger industrial regulations.

2297E563396C43CEA3BBBFEA728AE574.description: Review community science programs (e.g., Plantwatch) that engage the community and contribute to monitoring climate change.

B3193C3F14E0490BA745E90195CB4B4A.description: Discuss the long-term effects of climate change on wildlife and habitats.

B57C984BDB0649BD8E44E82920906B26.description: Investigate the cost of climate change on wildlife-related industries (e.g., hunting, fishing and tourism).

7A5D7681F99243588B5CE8163F25960B.description: Analyze how the implications of climate change on wildlife species and spaces may also indicate implications for humans.

84CF21E3BD5248B989AEF9B250787C0B.description: Examine the relationship between healthy ecosystems and carbon mitigation (e.g., role of peat bogs, marshland, grasslands and forests).

4FAE58899D6E409D8B880B39399FE7D1.description: Discuss how changing temperatures affect habitats (e.g., growing seasons, range of forest, algae blooms and expanding semi-arid areas).

8CFE975EDD29466294C5686B126A0EEA.description: Examine the impacts that increasing temperatures have on invasive species (e.g., ticks and mountain pine beetle) migrating through Saskatchewan.

984C52CB09AA4CF0AAD042B0DDECA5AE.description: Analyze the effects climate change has on managing wildlife populations, such as: stocking with fish species that have a greater tolerance for higher temperatures;, shifting hunting season to coincide with changes in rutting seasons; and, recording changes in migratory bird species.

1190CB928647478C88123E21EC012B04.description: Investigate the local and global impact climate change has on ecosystems (e.g., drought, fire and extreme weather).

22B2CE0066B24484B06C59C38FA2EA90.description: Examine the impact (e.g., relocation due to ice, water and forest fires) of climate change on Indigenous communities and culture.

72267297A2F84E298318DD797111D272.description: Define the term anthropogenic and how it relates to climate change.

B4C456EBCAC44878981621404D11456F.description: Discuss how climate changes over time through both natural and human processes.

45D1462F5592463BA96708915DD890F3.description: Investigate the impact that anthropogenic climate change has on habitat and wildlife populations.

C0E36DC92E274494A219E5D625D09BA7.description: Explore how species have adapted to habitat changes, such as: introduction of racoons and white-tailed deer to the prairies; and, range of moose expanding from forest to agriculture ecosystems.

A2770C3CB1414067891A7F33ABE410BC.description: Identify regulating factors for wildlife species within selected ecoregions of Saskatchewan, such as: food and water; habitat; predators, carrying capacity; species competition; and, disease and parasites.

DBEF30A4E57741689F9063BE39D31B9A.description: Explain the interactions of selected wildlife with other species and the environment, including: predator and prey relationships; keystone and indicator species; food chains and webs; and, symbiosis (e.g., parasitism, commensalism and mutualism).

23C911F82C7249FB8381307204E703E8.description: Explore how animals seek shelter in various landscapes (e.g., digging into snow and hiding under bushes).

B2920DDA13C64B50B441B8FF1C59C0DE.description: Discuss reasons for differences in the diversity of wildlife in Saskatchewan, such as adaptation, environmental changes, biotic and abiotic factors and human influences.

5D2FB12EB0B54D4D88BF22681B322127.description: Examine the role biodiversity has in determining the health of an ecosystem.

147A52C00C67450C9C6DAFCB2B840364.description: Explain how wildlife can be used as a barometer of overall environmental health.

9F69F740336D46038DD22B5E170A7D53.description: Examine the relationship between wildlife and ecosystems.

F306FB40DAA84B668BF2CC0FF4D3557F.description: Explain precautions (e.g., sanitization, wearing gloves, bleed and remove intestines quickly and keep meat cool) that can be taken to minimize the risks (e.g., contamination) of consuming game meat.

1059EA34632A49C78990BBCD81FDB766.description: Distinguish between threatening animal behaviours (e.g., pawing the ground and snarling) and normal behaviours (e.g., “escorting” humans away from a den) that do not pose a threat to humans.

04DFE6FEF5CD4218AA8F9AE2BF0073EA.description: Identify common game animals in Saskatchewan using distinguishing characteristics.

05E8A400249E4F4B8684D1EF21F33C93.description: Explore provincial and federal regulations specific for youth hunters.

5A4F77C731F24080AC27B5DBB6747AB7.description: Discuss requirements and best practices for obtaining permission to access private property for hunting.

890C3C62A21A4EEFAFDE3E2D995353A6.description: Research federal, provincial and municipal laws and regulations that prevent risk to Saskatchewan hunters, such as: lawful hunting hours; wearing high-visibility clothing when applicable; and, hunting prohibited from a vehicle without dispensation.

A6D38AD1AD6A4680AFD6F9C54F29D6A7.description: Explain what it means to be drawn for big game.

51EF60F66A434E50A6AE24B23104B6F7.description: Describe the steps to obtain a hunting license.

83D0B0CAE0C04FBD8A71F1D70CD9350B.description: Investigate regulations and safety requirements contained in the annual Saskatchewan Hunters and Trappers Guide.

CB6B410B96DC4386964BECED90A361DA.description: Explain the significance of access to wild game in the context of Indigenous food sovereignty.

3AA82A6A77BC49838C8028BB888E7CCA.description: Explore Treaty and Métis Aboriginal hunting rights and where they may be exercised in Saskatchewan.

B540DC53775242BEAFF9533C95030D9F.description: Investigate hunting regulations and safe hunting practices.

6AD80014F8AA430A876D5206E0750A6E.description: Hunting and Game - Safe Practices and Regulations (Core)

BC75CE1630234BAD83E2C52D1D0166B1.description: Investigate the role of local fishing industries (e.g., fish farms and fish hatcheries) in Saskatchewan.

0DDE496C0FCD47039456E5B048AB11CE.description: Identify the distinguishing characteristics (e.g., physical features, habitat, spawning habits, feeding habits and angling techniques) of major game fish species in Saskatchewan.

353F5F045CE54CFCA6FC025AF64D075C.description: Describe common ways of classifying fish, such as: species relationship (e.g., salmonids, percids and minnows); water temperature preference (e.g., cold and warm); and, feeding habits (e.g., fish eaters, insect eaters and plant eaters).

89FBEEB044DD41119D1E1A23DE662CEF.description: Analyze the factors (e.g., cost, eco-friendly and purpose) in selecting fishing equipment, such as: rods and reels (e.g., ice-fishing, tip ups and casting); tackle (e.g., spoons, jigs, rigs and lead-free); netting (e.g., gill net, dip net, seine net and trap net); and, bait sources.

D005B23324984A39BDAFF404CDB4E6BA.description: Investigate various types of fishing (e.g., jigging, casting, trolling, fly fishing and net).

D9FB55CB1CDA4D1FBD716A4C282EBFA9.description: Explain the differences between angling (i.e., uses a hook and line) and other types of fishing.

7168EC4C433E4EF1B5D8BBF4DD761074.description: Explain the significance of access to fish in the context of Indigenous food sovereignty.

05EE3FD0B3F645B4B6174D29D3952392.description: Investigate the fundamentals of angling and fishing.

A90C788CB49D48F08EA0A28E880A539B.description: Investigate the hunter, trapper and angler's responsibilities and procedures used to report conditions (e.g., habitat abuse and neglect of wildlife laws) that may endanger wildlife.

25215AFD46FB4D7696BA3B47B17B6A35.description: Explain the importance of completing a harvest survey, including: managing game; providing valuable information for quotas; tracking disease; and, season setting for the upcoming year.

961CDBE573F648B099D38F310F68DA40.description: Practise scoring game using characteristics of a variety of animals, such as: deer and elk (e.g., length of points and circumference of point); bear (e.g., jaw length and width); moose (e.g., length and width of palm); beaver (e.g., fur grade); and, fish (e.g., length and weight).

B2923BD4FA7D4BBF86418B20FCE7BD3B.description: Research the historical purpose (i.e., determine herd health and effectiveness of management practices) of scoring animals.

55E51232EFE24E9E830A4EE5CE4A417F.description: Compare and contrast commercial, sport, and Aboriginal and Treaty rightsprotected hunting, trapping and fishing.

BAC7CD6B92D34858AD10EB81E0766B9F.description: Investigate historical Indigenous tools and practices used for fishing (e.g., netting) and hunting (e.g., buffalo jump).

C04CD62F721144E795E9B1C1D117718B.description: Investigate ethical and traditional game harvesting practices, such as: only harvest what is needed; use all parts of animal; share harvest with Elders; appropriately dispose of carcass; and, leave tobacco behind.

6A515B0952524ECB9A42EEADE0EC98D7.description: Explore ethical and traditional game harvesting practices.

706C96F3C08C4672A091D51FD8FFE33E.description: Investigate how to erect a tent and secure it using pegs and guy lines.

96385314EBD1454FAB5910715919512F.description: Describe the function of various parts of a tent, such as: fly to keep out rain and wind; guy lines to support the tent against wind; groundsheet to protect the floor of the tent; and, poles to provide structure.

087076FC0FE149ACA3DD85C5317026FA.description: Investigate the benefits and drawbacks of different styles of tents.

F3358FAA996D44BA81E5EBD148B5E9A0.description: Explain the significance of the parts (e.g., bottom, fire, flaps and poles) of a tipi.

AE0F470FF70843A095EADE7BBCABFD71.description: Explore opportunities to participate in a tipi-raising.

367D3CBC74BE443B9DC1B4BB469497F8.description: Research traditional Indigenous shelters (e.g., tipi) and their purpose (e.g., housing, sweat and smudge).

D679F5F49B3F45AF91F82D66AC7FE53D.description: Discuss the cultural and traditional stories and teachings related to Indigenous shelters with an Elder or Knowledge Keeper.

F52ED55027D84B5B9A732A9213364653.description: Practise efficiency with tying knots for various purposes, such as: Anchor Knot or Non-Inverting Slippery Bowline (e.g., suspending a hammock); Friction Hitch, Prussik or Midshipman's Hitch (e.g., adjustable loop for length); Sheet Bend (e.g., connecting ropes of unequal diameter); Canadian Jam Knot (e.g., connecting two objects); and, Trucker's Hitch (e.g., securing loads).

CA2DE0FF2BF94786883F6A2B4459099D.description: Explain the properties of an effective knot (e.g., serves the purpose, easy to tie and easy to untie).

53E28C1746C1439B83B472CAEE0B6E08.description: Identify the basic families of knots (e.g., loops, hitches, bends and lashings).

445B573B05BC4AD8806FEAB30499928D.description: Review the properties of familiar knots (e.g., tying shoes).

13FFBBB69AA243EDB1E83A41E9E7A82C.description: Explore the materials (e.g., plant fibres and animal sources) used to make traditional Indigenous cordage.

416A92BA6159470FA40D181BD57548DB.description: Use a GPS to navigate a given route and arrive at a destination (e.g., geocaching).

5080C340E6BF4617B759ABF9110E6D36.description: Explain the basic functionality of a Global Positioning System (GPS).

14CCF31D4E814F598146799DDCD834A1.description: Determine individual pace length and use it to measure distances.

6842BA70A02945DC8EF4B9ACEAD8E3C9.description: Travel on a bearing without a map.

9963A0701080402FB8A34605708C7154.description: Explain the basic functionality of a compass, including the following terms: base plate; travel arrow; magnetic field; magnetic north; geographic “true” north; and, orienteering lines.

2CD3A624B06741248B26F09CD6B652A9.description: Research different types of navigation techniques (e.g., natural, celestial, compass and technological).

26DC4D2C0FAA4EFDA83B4DDECD89EAD6.description: Discuss Indigenous navigational skills and tools with an Elder or Knowledge Keeper.

24C37B5A409B469D90A927AEEF18633A.description: Explore basic and traditional navigational skills.

0B08F7F4E8D64CE591CF9831C49444F0.description: Research opportunities for outdoor skill certification (e.g., Paddle Canada).

2BFC9230127742BBB2E4B722F1254BB4.description: Investigate provincial and federal health and safety rules and guidelines for specific wilderness activities (e.g., hunting, fishing, trapping and camping).

A30CC26660544199AEA8FDFD74A79B85.description: Describe ways to reduce risk of personal injury (e.g., proper training, adhering to safety precautions and maintaining equipment) when participating in wilderness activities.

0E1DF7DD5B1549EAB45ADFD1BFC93493.description: Demonstrate safe practices (e.g., flagging, setting boundaries and carrying a whistle) when engaging in outdoor solitude.

46008F611A2D429BB1796EE8A2434D30.description: Identify potential hazards unique to wilderness excursions.

7404DDC1224B46EDBFC4A201FB777580.description: Explain the importance of establishing a trip plan and leaving it with someone before participating in a wilderness excursion.

776F7C5DEEAD4A61BD0E809E50E0AD80.description: Explore general safety practices when engaging in wilderness activities.

3F27225870734B4B8516F8F4EFB76069.description: Investigate how “Leave No Trace” guidelines may be applied in different geographical locations depending on population.

48328E97D0884654B4BE8A42B29EFF88.description: Explore opportunities for certification in “Leave No Trace” training.

147DD7F463CF4191B78D2B95AC8CE8BD.description: Describe how to leave the environment cleaner than found, such as picking up own and others' litter, including biodegradable material (e.g., sunflower seeds).

793DBEAB1D2144568A6E4192C896B912.description: Explain how pre-excursion planning minimizes resource damage.

7C926188596B47D08AC7280243C187F1.description: Discuss how the “Leave No Trace” principles align with traditional Indigenous practices, including the ethics of: conservation (i.e., not to take more than is needed); and, reciprocity (i.e., offer acts of thankfulness).

AFA045F68A064E05AA376B9175FDEBBC.description: Describe the “Leave No Trace” principles, including: plan ahead and prepare; travel and camp on durable surfaces; dispose of waste properly; leave what is found; minimize campfire impacts; respect wildlife; and, be considerate of other visitors.

50F05833B330414682E4A0BCE98F468C.description: Investigate the connection between “Leave No Trace” principles and traditional ways of sustainably living on the land.

0257EDDC2007467A817B44F12D6D37A4.description: Reflect on the cultural, physical, mental, emotional and spiritual benefits of land-based learning through outdoor solitude practices (e.g., sit-spot, sense of solitude and solo-time).

879DC005D15440268A234D1B7B6D1D73.description: Identify how benefits of nature are expressed through art (e.g., drama, literature, photography and paintings).

1CEDA7BEDFFD401186553B27215998A8.description: Explore outdoor pursuits that lead to personal growth and satisfaction.

D438810D874E45929503ACDBDAB55A5B.description: Maintain a journal (e.g., written, digital, photo journal or social media) to reflect on the cultural, physical, mental, emotional and spiritual benefits of outdoor experiences.

36B9635BEC3E4775ACE9BA925763F33A.description: Research the historical significance of the land upon which classroom excursions take place.

515A0CC396BC4503851C8D54BE74D91E.description: Discuss the spiritual benefits of spending time outdoors (e.g., connection to the land and sense of belonging).

3154232A97C948AD92C892AD41A9E1B4.description: Examine how time spent in nature contributes to managing emotions (e.g., reduces anger and promotes pleasure).

A9EB8E6CF6804544B54C8DDC9144B5A4.description: Investigate the mental benefits of being outside (e.g., helps prevent depression and reduces stress and anxiety).

E6A3ED4BCDC2464DBDEE44AFE90328A7.description: Explain the physical benefits of outdoor activities (e.g., improves overall well-being, increases vitamin D, lowers blood pressure and boosts immunity).

87E86435746E4C2A95050B71D2FF214E.description: Explore the Indigenous cultural learning opportunities (e.g., petroglyphs, pictographs, rubbing stones, tipi rings and traditional hunting grounds) in land-based learning.

D6462028234441F6B2D3E3E44259C46A.description: Discuss the meaning of land-based learning and its effect on human interactions with the environment (e.g., respecting animals and taking only what is needed).

9871083FC26D4B01BD39AE1A2AA0CAD1.description: Explore the cultural, physical, mental, emotional and spiritual benefits of land-based learning.
